job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Nice colleagues, friendly, engaged students
cons: Salaries are not so high

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: time off, team and students
cons: management, turn over and not family oriented

job_title: DEI Advocate in New York, NY
pros: Not much experience needed for this position.
cons: Not a long term position.

job_title: Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: I can't think of one pro for working here
cons: Constant firings and turnover and instead of rehiring they just pile the work on to their underpaid employees. If you ask for a raise for the additional work, they will literally tell you to "quit if you don't like your current salary/work"

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: The colleagues are all top notch. People really band together and help each other. Everyone consistently goes above and beyond to help each other and put students first. The students are also so creative and diverse. You really want to work hard for them and help them succeed. Nice that they give you a substantial winter break and also summer Fridays. Compared to non-profit higher ed, not as much red-tape. Willing to take risks and not everything requires a committee to make decisions.
cons: The pay is not competitive with other colleges in NYC. The benefits are also really poor compared to other colleges in general. At the time, you only got 5 sick and 5 vacation days, so you really had to plan ahead. During my final year there, they increased employee premiums for healthcare and reduced retirement contributions. The toughest part is working in for-profit higher ed if you came from non-profit - bottom line means something very different. Also, senior leadership (especially the president) is overly involved in everyday decision-making.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great people, energetic working environment
cons: none that I can think of

job_title: Student Admissions Ambassador in New York, NY
pros: Flexible schedule, works around your classes/internships/jobs
cons: Limits hours to 10 a week, minimum wage

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: nice students, flexible schedule, fun
cons: Pay isn't great, but not awful

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: academic freedom, student focused, engaged
cons: stagnant pay and compensation, adjunct dependent

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bayonne, NJ
pros: My entire experience with LIM was fantastic until my position was eliminated due to the pandemic. The students are fascinating, and the staff operates in a far more forward thinking manner than what I was originally accustomed to.
cons: Upon my dismissal from LIM, retrieving my belongings and communication with the school has been sparse. Assurances made that they would do everything they could to help have not held true. I still think it is a fantastic place to work, but I have been a little taken aback with the treatment I've received in recent months.

job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: Small. Good place to work. Easy to interact with other departments
cons: Pay- budget cuts hurt salaries for many

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Amount of holidays off from work
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Career Coach in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Friendly environment within campus community.
cons: Salary ranges could be better matched.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros:
Scheduling flexibility.
New York city location.
cons:
Low-performing student body with a very strong sense of entitlement. 
Low academic standards. Faculty is pressured to accept sub-par work to retain enrollment levels.  
Part time faculty expected to perform at full time capacity, at LAUGHABLE pay rates - roughly $200/week per undergraduate course. 
Zero growth opportunity.
No benefits. 
Institution recently pulled retirement savings match for full-time faculty. 
Recent cuts to full-time faculty roles.
No reliability in course assignments. 
"Let them eat cake" style of institutional leadership.

If you want to build a career in academia, care about academic rigor, or want to be part of a professional community that you can feel proud of -- STEER CLEAR.

job_title: Junior Systems Administrative in New York, NY
pros: Great exposure to new and cutting edge technology. Friendly team environment, management supports higher education and as a result you are encouraged to take  related certifications to your job function and you are reimbursed when passed.
cons: Need to have a solid understanding of  project management, the team is constantly working on new projects and the need for this skill will make or break you. If you are looking for a easy lay back job this is not the job, lots of work at times feel like another person or external consulting help is needed but you will leave with a sense of accomplishment at the end of the day.

review_title: In the midst of an image & culture overhaul. Will it take? Remains to be seen.
job_title: Mid-level Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
Physical plant, especially the Townhouse on E. 53rd St.
Benefits package, including 401K with employer matching
Yearly salary increases if good performer
Summer hours are reduced
LOTS of days off (most calendar holidays and a lot of snow days...it's a commuter school)
cons:
Deeply entrenched silos make intra-departmental work difficult
Poor communication between departments, especially between academics and administration
Poor internal communication overall, people don't seem to know or understand institutional mission or direction
Lots and LOTS of meetings
Resistance to remote work or other alternative work arrangements; HR could use modernizing
Those who wield power, like HR or middle management, wield it with an iron fist
Outdated corporate culture based on gossip and favoritism

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth and responsibility. Its a good stepping stone and a place to build skills. Fairly easy to conceptualize and run with new projects or ideas. Good location, modern/new buildings. Lots of time off and always closes for snow or bad weather.
cons: It's a for-profit College, so the students feel more like customers than students which is not ideal in an educational environment, especially when grading is involved. Many people are overloaded with work for not nearly enough pay.  Work is sometimes added to your plate and you are not given a choice. Managers don't care and upper admin. cares even less. Some processes are inefficient.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros:
-good location in manhattan
-creative students
-great library
cons:
-little to no growth opportunity (even with top reviews and positive feedback)
-terrible pay 
-zero benefits
-no  job  security and little transparency when it comes to future course scheduling

review_title: A good school with positive vibes, but low pay

review_title: A for-profit school that treats faculty like office workers.

cons: Low pay and respect for faculty members. Many staff are in offices, faculty in cubicles. Faculty are "at will" employees. There has recently been a reorganization with attrition.
